Ten of the Most Exciting Ways to Commemorate America‚Äôs 250th This Year
Our country‚Äôs birthday bash includes exhibitions, historical reenactments, a massive potluck and more
America is celebrating 250 years of independence in 2026 with a bevy of activities, events, exhibitions, concerts, performances and festivities from coast-to-coast. As one would expect, the Smithsonian Institution is joining in on the year-long celebrations. The National Portrait Gallery will host its ‚Äú250th Festival: Celebrating Our Story‚Äù on February 14, with gallery tours, live music and dance performances, art-making activities, and more. The National Museum of American History will open its exhibition, ‚ÄúIn Pursuit of Life, Liberty and Happiness,‚Äù this spring with 250 objects that tell America‚Äôs story, including President Abraham Lincoln‚Äôs top hat and a faux pearl necklace worn by Abigail Adams. Meanwhile, the renovations at Smithsonian Castle will pause and it will open to welcome public visitors from Memorial Day weekend through Labor Day. Along with a caf√© and visitor‚Äôs center, the space will feature a special exhibition, ‚ÄúAmerican Aspirations,‚Äù which reflects on the nation‚Äôs history and ideals with artifacts like abolitionist Harriet Tubman‚Äôs hymnal. And the annual Smithsonian Folklife Festival will expand into a larger celebration, ‚ÄúOf the People: The Smithsonian Festival of Festivals,‚Äù which pulls together 40 different festivals highlighting the country‚Äôs rich cultural traditions.
From a flotilla of tall sailing ships stopping at port cities along the United States‚Äô eastern coast to the opening of a new presidential library in North Dakota, America is ringing in its semiquincentennial in a myriad of ways. Here are 10 opportunities to celebrate America‚Äôs spirit, resilience and history across the nation.
‚ÄúThe Declaration‚Äôs Journey‚Äù
Where: Museum of the American Revolution; Philadelphia
Dates: Now through January 3, 2027
When the authors of the Declaration of Independence wrote this pivotal document 250 years ago, they had no idea how influential it would become. In the two-and-a-half centuries since, America‚Äôs formal statement announcing its separation from Great Britain has become a blueprint of freedom directly inspiring revolutions and serving as a charter for the oppressed. It‚Äôs also sparked debates on topics including equality and individual rights.
More than 100 nations have adopted the ideals of the Declaration of Independence into their own fights for freedom. ‚ÄúThe Declaration‚Äôs Journey‚Äù exhibition explores this global impact, as well as the document‚Äôs complex history and legacy, through the display of more than 120 objects. These include early newspapers spreading word of the Declaration, a civil rights petition signed by 71 free Black Philadelphians that was sent to Congress in 1799, and a massive printing press used to launch Chile‚Äôs first newspaper, Aurora de Chile, and propel Chilean independence.
Along with a short film spotlighting how the Declaration has inspired independence movements from Haiti to Ukraine, the in-depth exhibition also features accompanying programming, including a ten-part PBS series that traces the story of the Declaration of Independence around the globe.
‚ÄúAmericana at 250: Eagles, Flags and Uncle Sam‚Äù
Where: New Mexico History Museum; Santa Fe, New Mexico
Dates: February 13, 2026‚ÄìJanuary 18, 2027
When the Declaration of Independence was written and signed in 1776, New Mexico was known as Santa Fe de Nuevo M√©xico. This province of the Spanish Empire didn‚Äôt become a U.S. state until January 6, 1912. The New Mexico History Museum‚Äôs year-long exhibition, ‚ÄúAmericana at 250: Eagles, Flags and Uncle Sam,‚Äù highlights this unique perspective, including what it means to be both American and Nuevo Mexicano.
On display are 17 symbols of Americana that speak to freedom and strength, as well as shifting ideas of citizenship and national identity, over 250 years. These include a rare souvenir ribbon from President Theodore Roosevelt‚Äôs 1903 Santa Fe visit, a bronze figurative sculpture of the Statue of Liberty by American artist Fritz Scholder, and a political satire cartoon criticizing the U.S. Congress‚Äô delay in admitting new territories, including New Mexico. The exhibition also features regular screenings of ‚ÄúRioGrande,‚Äù a short movie sponsored by the New Mexico American Revolution Bicentennial Commission in 1976 to celebrate American patriotism.
America‚Äôs Potluck
Where: Cities throughout U.S.
Date: July 5, 2026
America‚Äôs Potluck serves as an opportunity for neighbors to come together over food and conversation. This nationwide event, which occurs on July 5, calls on cities, towns and neighborhoods to create their own potluck gatherings in the tradition of Sunday night dinner, and to slow down and connect. Once registered, each potluck‚Äîwhich can be anything from small get-togethers to community-wide festivities‚Äîwill appear on the America‚Äôs Potluck map, and any event marked ‚Äúpublic‚Äù is open to everyone. Get to know your neighbors, revel in diverse cuisines and celebrate the rich tapestry of cultures, races and histories that make up America‚Äôs identity.
The America‚Äôs Potluck website even features a downloadable bingo card with prompts like ‚ÄúFound someone who‚Äôs been to a national park,‚Äù and ‚ÄúSwapped a recipe or a cooking shortcut.‚Äù Get five in a row and you win, in more ways than one. You learn a bit about your neighbors in the process.
Symphonic celebrations
Where: Symphony Center in Chicago, and elsewhere
Dates: Various dates
Joining other musical ensembles across the nation, the Chicago Symphony Orchestra is commemorating the country‚Äôs anniversary through its concerts. In this case, it‚Äôs a monthlong showcase of American music. America 250: A Musical Journey is a series of programs throughout June honoring the nation‚Äôs resilience and creativity. Highlights include Wynton Marsalis‚Äô Liberty symphony with the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra (June 4-6), Marsalis‚Äô new arrangements to masterworks by artists such as Duke Ellington and Thelonious Monk (June 2) and a tribute to John Williams and Steven Spielberg (June 23), showcasing the 50-year partnership of two legendary innovators through iconic cinematic scores, such as those from the Indiana Jones movies, E.T. and Jaws.
Other classical music events are happening across the country. In Idaho, the Boise Philharmonic is celebrating America‚Äôs 250th birthday by opening each of its Classical Symphony concerts with a work by an American composer. In Milwaukee, Copland & Twain: An America 250 Celebration, a theatrical concert by the Buffalo Philharmonic Orchestra, Milwaukee Symphony Orchestra and Ravinia Festival, brings together the atmospheric music of American composer Aaron Copland with author Mark Twain‚Äôs observations of a changing America.
Sail250
Where: Various cities
When: Various dates
More than 50 tall ships and military ships from around the globe will gather to honor America‚Äôs 250th anniversary with a maritime tour along the East Coast. Beginning in New Orleans, this impressive flotilla will work its way northward, making stops in host cities in Virginia, Maryland, New York/New Jersey and Massachusetts. Along with a fleet of majestic ships like the ARA Libertad, a steel-hulled, three-masted sailing vessel belonging to the Argentine Navy, and the Gorch Fock, the German Navy‚Äôs 266-foot-long, three-masted barque, Sail250 will bring the public together with an array of international crews and cadets for parades, concerts and regional events, such as an air show over Baltimore Harbor. Over the Fourth of July weekend, a celebration at the Port of New York and New Jersey will include a Statue of Liberty salute.
Historical reenactments
Where: Fort Ticonderoga, New York, and elsewhere
When: Various dates
Historical reenactments are a way of bringing history to life through period-era costumes, battle drills and key moments in time. As part of America‚Äôs celebration, New York‚Äôs Fort Ticonderoga invites visitors to step into the past and experience ‚ÄúReal Time Revolution,‚Äù an immersive reenactment of the events before and during the Revolutionary War, on the dates when they actually took place. You might encounter the Northern Continental Army as it retreats to Ticonderoga (July 3-5) or watch the Continental Army hold the line for liberty against the first major southerly advance by British soldiers, which occurred at Fort Ticonderoga in the fall of 1776 (October 24-25), among the fort‚Äôs other real-time events.
Or head to Boston on March 17 for Evacuation Day Boston 250, a grand-scale celebration marking the departure of the British Army after a ten-month siege. Along with a parade and a flyover, several reenacting units will be there to commemorate this turning point in the American story. And at New Jersey‚Äôs Washington Crossing State Park in December, you can watch the reenactments of George Washington‚Äôs 1776 crossing of the Delaware River, which is often hailed as one of the general‚Äôs ‚Äúbest tactical decisions in the American Revolution.‚Äù
Spirit of Independence Festival
Where: National Archives Foundation, Washington, D.C.
Dates: June 4-6, 2026
The National Archives in Washington, D.C. is home to some of America's most prominent historical documents, including the original Declaration of Independence and the Constitution of the United States. It‚Äôs also home to the National Archives Foundation, an independent partner of the archives, which will host a three-day Spirit of Independence Festival from June 4-6, 2026. The event will take place over two blocks along Constitution Avenue, right outside the National Archives building, with historical reenactments and a dramatic reading of the Declaration. You can also expect hands-on, family-friendly activities that connect visitors with sites across the country.
Opening the week of April 24, the National Archives Foundation will also host ‚ÄúFree and Independent,‚Äù an exhibition showcasing the events, people and ideals that led to the Declaration‚Äôs signing and illuminating how the document‚Äôs ideals and spirit have appeared in culture, art and society.
Iowa State Fair
Where: Des Moines
When: August 13-23, 2026
State fairs are the epitome of Americana, from serving as cultural showcases for local innovation, art and heritage, to dishing out tasty treats like corn dogs and chocolate chip cookies. They‚Äôre also symbols of patriotism. This year, the Iowa State Fair is encouraging visitors to embrace the year‚Äôs theme of ‚ÄúFair Spirit.‚Äù The 2026 festivities will focus on agriculture, industry and the American dream. Attend a livestock show, ride a giant slide, take in some live music and shop for anything from hot tubs to hand-carved wooden spoons. The fair is especially known for its food on a stick, with more than 50 offerings, including pickle-on-a-stick, bacon balls and deep-fried strawberry shortcake.
America 250 at George Washington‚Äôs Mount Vernon
Where: Mount Vernon, Virginia
Dates: Throughout 2026The former residence of founding father George Washington is getting in on America‚Äôs 250th birthday festivities with a new exhibition honoring the first president‚Äôs revolutionary life and the completion of a multiyear renovation. The estate‚Äôs first and second floors are now welcoming tours, following nearly two years of room closures. You can now see Washington‚Äôs newly restored bedchamber, complete with reproduction 1790s wallpaper and authentic Washington family furnishings, and marvel at the eye-catching watercolors adorning his Little Parlor, which was used as a space of informal socializing.
Opening this spring, the estate‚Äôs immersive exhibition, ‚ÄúGeorge Washington: A Revolutionary Life,‚Äù reexamines Washington‚Äôs legacy and how the decisions he made continue to impact us. Step inside a re-creation of the President's House in Philadelphia, where Washington lived from 1790 to 1797, and listen to important conversations that took place during the nation‚Äôs founding. Or partake in the ‚ÄúBe Washington‚Äù interactive presentation and take on the general‚Äôs role, facing some of the challenges that he did.
The property also features the new Patriots Path: a Revolutionary War Encampment, in which you can visit the re-creation of an 18th-century Continental Army encampment and interact with historical interpreters, learning about what life was like as a soldier.
Theodore Roosevelt Presidential Library
Where: Medora, North Dakota
Date: Opens July 4, 2026
Theodore Roosevelt had an undeniable connection to Medora, North Dakota. He arrived to the larger Dakota Territory to hunt bison in 1883, invested in a ranch (and eventually, a second one), and later returned to the area‚Äôs rugged Badlands to mourn the deaths of his wife and mother. He often credits what‚Äôs now North Dakota as the place where ‚Äúthe romance of [his] life began,‚Äù inspiring his lifelong dedication to environmental conservation and‚Äîthrough a series of frontier challenges‚Äîhelping prepare him for the leadership role of president.
Scheduled to open in Medora on July 4, the new Theodore Roosevelt Presidential Library will showcase the legacy of America‚Äôs 26th president through items such as personal letters and writings, including a diary from after his wife‚Äôs and mother's deaths, and a deep dive into his ranching and military life. A series of chronologically arranged narrative galleries will take visitors through eight chapters of Roosevelt‚Äôs life, beginning with his childhood in New York City and include transparency about his complicated legacy.
In addition to its interactive displays and hands-on learning experiences, the library serves as a model for environmental stewardship‚Äîbuilt on top of a butte on the edge of town and blending into the Badlands landscape with rammed earth and prairie roofs, along with an outdoor boardwalk loop‚Äîembodying Roosevelt‚Äôs own conservation beliefs.

Renaissance Readers Left Chemical Clues Inside These Medical Manuals. Were They Using Human Feces and Tortoise Shells to Treat Illnesses?
Researchers analyzed proteins extracted from ‚ÄúHow to Cure and Expel All Afflictions and Illnesses of the Human Body‚Äù and ‚ÄúA Useful and Essential Little Book of Medicine for the Common Man,‚Äù both written by a 16th-century German eye doctor
In the 16th century, a German doctor published recipe books featuring cures for ailments like bad breath, mouth ulcers and hair loss. Now, scientists have analyzed traces of proteins found inside these medical manuals, and they‚Äôve identified evidence of plants, animals, and human sweat and feces.
According to the researchers, their study, which was published in the journal American Historical Review, marks the first proteomic analysis of Renaissance recipes. They found evidence that readers may have been creating concoctions described in the texts and experimenting with alternative ingredients.
‚ÄúAs historians, we always struggle with the limitations of reconstructing the experimentation and getting to know what actually happened when these people experimented and changed ingredients,‚Äù lead author Stefan Han√ü, a historian at the University of Manchester in England, tells Chemical & Engineering News‚Äô Bethany Halford. ‚ÄúThe idea was to get a better understanding of what was actually going on at the workshop or at the household kitchen where they brewed all these remedies.‚Äù
The texts in question are How to Cure and Expel All Afflictions and Illnesses of the Human Body and A Useful and Essential Little Book of Medicine for the Common Man, both published by the German eye doctor Bartholom√§us Vogtherr in 1531. Bound together into one volume, the manuals belong to the University of Manchester‚Äôs John Rylands Research Institute and Library.
Per the study, the books‚Äô margins are covered in notes by 16th- and 17th-century readers. The researchers focused on clues found in places where these individuals‚Äô fingers touched the page. They also conducted archival research to contextualize their findings.
‚ÄúPeople always leave molecular traces on the pages of books and other documents when they come into contact with paper,‚Äù co-author Gleb Zilberstein, a biotechnology expert and inventor, tells Live Science‚Äôs Kristina Killgrove in an email. ‚ÄúThese traces include components of sweat, sometimes saliva, metabolites, contaminants and environmental components.‚Äù
Zilberstein adds that these traces are ‚Äúoften invisible to the naked eye.‚Äù To study them, the researchers extracted proteins from the pages with special plastic diskettes. They then used mass spectrometry to help identify these samples. Per the study, the researchers sequenced 111 proteins, which they then attempted to match to known materials in databases.
The researchers detected evidence of European beech, watercress and rosemary next to recipes for hair growth tonics that call for those ingredients. Meanwhile, another hair loss treatment detailed in the manual involves rubbing human feces on bald spots. Next to these instructions, the researchers identified lipocalin, a type of protein that may have ‚Äúcome from the contents of someone‚Äôs chamber pot,‚Äù as Popular Mechanics‚Äô Elizabeth Rayne writes.
The researchers also found collagen peptides that may have come from tortoise shells or lizards. Per the study, these reptiles were ‚Äúpraised for their medicinal qualities in 16th-century Germany,‚Äù and some hair loss recipes from this period called for dried, crushed lizard heads. Because the collagen peptides were found near Vogtherr‚Äôs hair-growth recipes, the researchers think the readers might have been experimenting with using lizards for this purpose.
Quick fact: Turtles in medicine
In 1563, the Swiss naturalist Conrad Gessner wrote that turtle shells could cure cataracts and edema and counteract snake and scorpion venom, according to the study.
Additionally, the pages featured collagen peptides that may have come from a hippopotamus. Found near recipes for mouth and scalp ailments, the proteins provide insights into the global trade of medicinal ingredients during this period, Han√ü tells Chemical & Engineering News.
According to the study, some 16th-century experts thought hippopotamus teeth could treat toothaches. The researchers think some of Vogtherr‚Äôs readers may have ‚Äústruggled with severe teeth problems.‚Äù Someone appears to have highlighted the books‚Äô cures for black teeth, ‚Äústinking‚Äù breath and mouth ulcers. One handwritten recipe, added to the printed text, is labeled, ‚ÄúFor the days of toothaches and for ulcers.‚Äù
The team was surprised to find remnants of ingredients that weren‚Äôt mentioned in the manuals but were common during this era. These discoveries suggest that Vogtherr‚Äôs readers were testing out new recipes. Han√ü explains to Chemical & Engineering News, ‚ÄúWe could see experimentation taking place.‚Äù
‚ÄúIn the future, we plan to expand this work and examine other historical books,‚Äù Zilberstein tells Live Science. He says the team also hopes to ‚Äúidentify individual readers based on their proteomic data.‚Äù
The study is ‚Äúan outstanding example of how research in history and in the natural sciences can learn from and benefit each other,‚Äù says Pamela H. Smith, a historian at Columbia University who wasn‚Äôt involved in the research, to Chemical & Engineering News. ‚ÄúMore work needs to be carried out, but this is a really interesting and suggestive first foray. The originality and innovation of the study cannot be overstated.‚Äù

articles.content:
Dinosaur National Monument Construction Work Turns Up New Fossils, Leading to the First Excavation at One Site in More Than a Century
Recent digs revealed roughly 20 feet of a long-necked dinosaur‚Äôs skeleton, and paleontologists suspect even more bones are lurking underground
Construction work at Dinosaur National Monument recently turned up an apt surprise: dinosaur fossils.
Paleontologists believe that the remains, which were discovered last fall, belonged to a large, long-necked sauropod‚Äîmost likely a member of the Diplodocus genus, according to a January 16 statement. These dinosaurs roamed the Earth around 150 million years ago.
The first fossils emerged on September 16, 2025, in a parking lot just east of the park‚Äôs Quarry Exhibit Hall in Utah, which features a wall of roughly 1,500 dinosaur bones. After crews removed some old asphalt, paleontologists discovered a huge shin bone that had been hiding in the sandstone just inches beneath the surface.
They paused the construction work, kept looking and soon found even more bones: 14 tail vertebrae, some limb bones and ‚Äúa few toes,‚Äù says ReBecca Hunt-Foster, a paleontologist at the park, to the Colorado Sun‚Äôs Parker Yamasaki.
In the end, the team removed roughly 3,000 pounds of fossils and rock from mid-September to mid-October last year. The excavations revealed roughly 20 feet of a dinosaur‚Äôs skeleton, and paleontologists suspect even more bones might still be underground. But they‚Äôll wait until the weather warms up in the spring to continue digging.
‚ÄúThere‚Äôs still more in the ground,‚Äù Hunt-Foster tells the Denver Gazette‚Äôs Seth Boster, adding that she thinks they might eventually find a ‚Äúreasonably complete‚Äù skeleton. ‚ÄúSo, we plan on renewing our excavation efforts as soon as winter passes and it‚Äôs safe to do so. And we‚Äôll see what else we find.‚Äù
Most of the newfound remains are now housed at the Utah Field House of Natural History State Park Museum, where experts are cleaning and studying them. But some are on display at the Quarry Exhibit Hall. Meanwhile, construction crews have finished their project, which included concrete and asphalt work, as well as accessibility improvements.
Did you know? Dinos everywhere
In January 2025, paleontologists discovered a 67.5-million-year-old partial dinosaur bone beneath the parking lot of the Denver Museum of Nature and Science. They found the bone‚Äîa vertebra that once belonged to a plant-eating dinosaur‚Äîburied 763 feet deep while taking a geologic core sample.
According to park officials, the bones represent the first fossils recovered from that site since 1924. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve had lots of excavations and lots of new discoveries around the park, but not on this particular part of the quarry,‚Äù Hunt-Foster tells the Denver Gazette.
Split between eastern Utah and western Colorado, the 210,000-acre Dinosaur National Monument was officially established in 1915. But its history dates back much further‚Äîto at least the Late Jurassic Period, roughly 163.5 million to 145 million years ago. At that time, North America was located farther south than it is today, and the Rocky Mountains had not yet begun to rise. The region that would eventually become the park‚Äîknown as the Morrison ecosystem‚Äîwas warm and humid.
Ferns, cycads, ginkgos, horsetails and giant conifer trees‚Äîwhich towered as high as today‚Äôs tallest redwoods‚Äîcovered the landscape. The lush forests and shrublands were home to all sorts of creatures, from small, rodent-like animals to gargantuan dinosaurs.
Scientists know all of this today because of the Morrison Formation, a layer of rock beneath much of the western United States. The formation is made up of various types of sandstone, mudstone and limestone‚Äîall hardened versions of sediment that was deposited by rivers, streams and lakes millions of years ago. The sediment also preserved myriad dinosaur bones, as well as other clues about the region‚Äôs prehistoric past.
Many dinosaurs that visitors can see at the Quarry Exhibit Hall may have died from severe droughts long before an asteroid strike roughly 66 million years ago led to the extinction of all non-avian dinosaurs.
Their bones were discovered millions of years later by paleontologists. At the site that would become Dinosaur National Monument, the first digs were led by Earl Douglass, who was tasked with unearthing intact dinosaur bones and sending them back to the Carnegie Museum of Natural History in Pittsburgh for display. Subsequent digs were conducted by researchers from the Smithsonian‚Äôs National Museum of Natural History and the University of Utah.
Paleontologists weren‚Äôt all that surprised that the recent construction work produced several fossils. The parking lot that the crews were fixing was built atop the remnants of those original, early 20th-century digs, per the Colorado Sun.
Even so, it‚Äôs still funny to think that ‚Äúso many people have been driving over [the dinosaur] for decades and it was just right underneath the surface,‚Äù Hunt-Foster tells the Denver Gazette.
‚ÄúIt just goes to show you never know what‚Äôs right under your feet,‚Äù she adds.

The Earliest Known Vertebrates Had Four Eyes‚Äîand They Worked a Lot Like Ours Do, New Research Suggests
Two of those eyes may have evolved into a part of the brain called the pineal gland
Many spine-bearing creatures, or vertebrates, have a curious bit of tissue deep in their brains called the pineal gland. It helps regulate sleep rhythms by reacting to light detected by the eyes. Sometimes, the gland is even nicknamed the ‚Äúthird eye.‚Äù
Now, new research hints that this label might not be so far-fetched. The earliest known fossil vertebrates, from 518 million years ago, may have viewed the world through four eyes‚Äîand one pair of them was the precursor to the pineal gland, according to a study published January 21 in the journal Nature. The findings, which also provide the oldest known evidence of ‚Äúcamera-type‚Äù eyes, suggest that these early animals had a more intricate visual system than previously thought.
The studied specimens represent myllokunmingids, a group of jawless fish that were each around one inch long. From 2019 to 2024, researchers collected several fossils of two myllokunmingid species from a famous bonebed in southern China. The site documents the evolution of animals during the Cambrian Period, which was around 541 million to 485.4 million years ago.
Fun fact: Chengjiang Fossil Site
This fossil location is a UNESCO World Heritage Site in China‚Äôs Yunnan province. Recovered specimens, which represent hundreds of species, preserve a record of an early Cambrian marine community, particularly during the Cambrian explosion. That was a period around 530 million years ago when animals were rapidly evolving, leading to a burst in biodiversity.
The recovered fossils preserved the creatures‚Äô soft body parts‚Äîincluding a pair of bigger, recognizable eyes on the sides of the head. That‚Äôs rare because such tissues often deteriorate before natural processes preserve them.
But peering at the myllokunmingids through a high-powered microscope uncovered something the researchers didn‚Äôt expect. ‚ÄúWe started by examining the obvious large eyes to understand their anatomy‚Äîand it was a complete surprise to find two smaller, fully functional eyes between them,‚Äù study co-author Peiyun Cong, a paleobiologist at Yunnan University in China, says in a statement.
Further analyses identified pigment-containing structures called melanosomes in the tiny, central eyes. Melanosomes give color to the irises and protect the eyes from getting too much light. The team also found round structures that look like lenses, suggesting that the eyes could do more than detect light; they could form images, too.
‚ÄúThey likely could see objects quite well, telling their shape and some degree of three-dimensionality,‚Äù study co-author Jakob Vinther, a paleontologist at the University of Bristol in England, tells New Scientist‚Äôs James Woodford. ‚ÄúThey likely also had a broad view of their surroundings, sort of IMAX-style, thanks to their four eyes.‚Äù
Ultimately, the work hinted that all four eyes were camera-type, which is the variety found in humans and most modern vertebrates. Each eye has a single lens and iris to focus the right amount of light onto a region in the back called the retina.
Since modern vertebrate eyes and the pineal gland develop from the same precursor cells‚Äîand some jawless fish alive today have light-detecting pineal organs atop their heads‚Äîthe researchers posit that the ancient, tiny eyes they found eventually gave rise to the pineal gland. ‚ÄúOnly later in evolution did they shrink, lose visual power and take on their modern role in regulating sleep,‚Äù Cong says in the statement.
Tetsuto Miyashita, a paleobiologist at the Canadian Museum of Nature who wasn‚Äôt involved in the research, tells New Scientist that he isn‚Äôt fully convinced. ‚ÄúDoes it really make so much sense to have so many prominent eyes on the head?‚Äù
Still, the work‚Äôs broad findings make sense with other recent research. A study published January 28 in the journal Proceedings of the Royal Society B also hints that some of the earliest vertebrates had more advanced eyes than researchers expected. Fossils of ancient jawless fish recovered from Scotland suggest that the creatures had complex, camera-type eyes around 443 million years ago.
‚ÄúI love how our findings fit with work from other groups,‚Äù Jane Reeves, co-author of the more recent study and a paleobiologist at the University of Manchester in England, tells BBC Wildlife Magazine‚Äôs Will Newton when asked about the Nature paper. ‚ÄúWhen you put our respective research together, they connect to fill in a lot of gaps in our knowledge, creating a really well-supported picture of the early evolution of vertebrates.‚Äù
